column4: A survey diagram must include a representation of each parcel in the CSD as a polygon or polyhedron if the parcel is not an existing centre-line easement for which all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the width of the centre-line easement is unknown\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the width of the centre-line easement is accepted within a large rural parcel with accepted boundaries.

Signifier: A water boundary may be adopted
Statement: A water boundary may be adopted
column4: An existing water boundary may be adopted when the margin of the water body has moved as a result of accretion only if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the margin of the water body has not also moved as a result of erosion or the water boundary is an accepted boundary\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the CSD does not have a survey purpose that is a claim for accretion.

Signifier: A water centreline boundary may be adopted
Statement: A water centreline boundary may be adopted
column4: An existing irregular boundary that followed the centre-line of a water body may be adopted only if the existing irregular boundary is adopted as a water centre-line boundary.
A new boundary must not be a water centre-line boundary.
A boundary that defines a primary parcel must not be an accepted boundary if there is a risk of the boundary encroaching on another parcel.
A boundary that defines a new primary parcel must not be an accepted boundary if the primary parcel is not a majority successor parcel.

A boundary that defines a primary parcel must not be an accepted boundary if all of the following are false:
- the boundary is a right-line boundary that does not have a boundary bearing or have a boundary distance in an approved CSD
- the boundary has a boundary bearing that is a magnetic bearing and the reorientation of the boundary bearing cannot be determined without measurement
- the boundary defines a balance parcel that is included in a title that is to remain limited as to parcels and accuracy [relative] between boundary points included in the boundary does not meet class C accuracy
- the boundary defines a balance parcel that is included in a title that is to remain a Hawkes Bay interim title and accuracy [relative] between boundary points included in the boundary does not meet class C accuracy
- the boundary is a water boundary or a water centre-line boundary that defines a balance parcel that is included in a title that is to remain limited as to parcels
- the boundary is a water boundary or a water centre-line boundary that defines a balance parcel that is included in a title that is to remain Hawkes bay interim title
- the boundary is an existing irregular boundary.
A boundary point must be accepted if the boundary point is included in a boundary that is an accepted boundary.
A boundary that defines a non-primary parcel may be an accepted boundary only if the boundary is within a large rural parcel defined by accepted boundaries.

A new water boundary that defines a non-primary parcel coinciding with an existing water boundary that defines a primary parcel must be considered an accepted water boundary only if the non-primary parcel is over any of the following bodies of water:
- a stream
- a river
- a lake
- a common marine and coastal area.

Signifier: Accounting for erosion when water boundary not accepted
Statement: Accounting for erosion when water boundary not accepted
column4: An existing water boundary must be defined by survey if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the margin of the water body has moved as a result of erosion\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the water boundary is not an accepted boundary.

Signifier: Accretion, stream bed and adverse possesion area
Statement: Accretion, stream bed and adverse possesion area
column4:
An area [quantity] must be assigned to a portion of land that has any of the following survey purpose:
- a claim for accretion
- a claim for a dry stream bed
- a claim for adverse possession.

Signifier: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting a water or irregular boundary 1
Statement: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting a water or irregular boundary 1
column4: The boundary bearing of a right line boundary that intersects a water or irregular boundary must be defined to a level of accuracy [positional] that is consistent with the accuracy class of the right line boundary.

Signifier: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting a water or irregular boundary 2
Statement: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting a water or irregular boundary 2
column4: The boundary distance of a right line boundary that intersects a water or irregular boundary must be defined to a level of accuracy [positional] that is consistent with the accuracy [positional] of the water or irregular boundary.

Signifier: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting an accepted water boundary 1
Statement: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting an accepted water boundary 1
column4: The boundary bearing of a right line boundary that intersects an accepted water boundary must be defined to a level of accuracy [positional] that is consistent with the accuracy class of the right line boundary.

Signifier: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting an accepted water boundary 2
Statement: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting an accepted water boundary 2
column4: The boundary distance of a right line boundary that intersects an accepted water boundary must be defined to a level of accuracy [positional] that is consistent with the accuracy [positional] of the water boundary.

Signifier: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting an offset water boundary 1
Statement: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting an offset water boundary 1
column4: A boundary bearing of a right line boundary that intersects an offset water boundary must meet a level of accuracy [positional] that is consistent with the accuracy class of the right line boundary.

Signifier: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting an offset water boundary 2
Statement: Accuracy [positional] for right line boundary intersecting an offset water boundary 2
column4: The boundary distance of a right line boundary that intersects an offset water boundary need not be defined.

A boundary point that is included in a new boundary must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary point and each other boundary point that is included in another boundary is less than the horizontal distance and less than the slope distance between the boundary points.
A boundary must be accurately defined.

Signifier: Accurate relation of non-primary parcel boundaries to underlying parcel boundaries
Statement: Accurate relation of non-primary parcel boundaries to underlying parcel boundaries
column4: A boundary that defines a non-primary parcel must be accurately related to each boundary that defines an underlying parcel if the underlying parcel is not created by the same cadastral survey as the non-primary parcel.

Signifier: Adopted mark not used as PRM
Statement: Adopted mark not used as PRM
column4: An adopted mark must not be used as a permanent reference mark.

An adopted piece of information must be copied from the source of the information without change if the information is not any of the following:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the conversion of units of measure\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- a bearing adjustment.

Signifier: Ambiguity and overlap of water or irregular boundaries
Statement: Ambiguity and overlap of water or irregular boundaries
column4: A water or irregular boundary that is not an accepted boundary must have its position determined to a level of accuracy [positional] that prevents a parcel defined by the boundary overlapping another parcel.
A CSD may be an approved CSD only if the CSD is a complete CSD.

A balance parcel may be derived only from any of the following primary parcels:
- a railway parcel that is not in a record of title
- a road parcel
- a fixed marginal strip
- the bed of a lake
- the bed of a river
- the bed of a stream
- the bed of the sea
- an access way that is not in a record of title
- a service lane that is not in a record of title.

A water or irregular boundary must not be considered any of the following:
- a class A boundary
- a class B boundary
- a class C boundary
- a class D boundary.
A boundary must be considered a boundary that is coincident with another boundary if the boundary is intended to lie exactly on top of the other boundary.
A boundary must be considered a boundary that is converted if the boundary is replaced by another boundary that is not of the same boundary form.

Signifier: Boundary for balance or residual parcel being accepted
Statement: Boundary for balance or residual parcel being accepted
column4: An existing boundary that defines a balance parcel or defines a residue parcel may be an accepted boundary only if there is no other new parcel defined by the boundary.
A boundary must be considered a boundary that intersects another boundary if the boundaries consist of the same boundary point.

Signifier: Boundary mark on existing boundary point 1
Statement: Boundary mark on existing boundary point 1
column4:
A mark must be placed at a boundary point that is included in an existing boundary that defines a new primary parcel if it is practicable for the mark to be placed at the boundary point and any of the following is true:
- the boundary point is subject to conflict
- the definition of the boundary in an approved CSD is not sufficient to determine the compliance of the boundary with the applicable accuracy standard
- the boundary is only defined in a diagram on transfer
- the boundary defines a parcel from which limitation as to parcels is being uplifted
- the parcel is subject to a claim for adverse possession
- the boundary point is recorded in a Maori Land CSD that is annotated computed plan – areas and boundaries not defined by survey"
- the boundary is recorded in a Maori Land CSD that is annotated "computed plan – areas and boundaries not defined by survey"
- the boundary point is an unmarked boundary point that was included in boundaries that defined only non-primary parcels."

Signifier: Boundary mark on existing boundary point 2
Statement: Boundary mark on existing boundary point 2
column4:
A mark must be placed at a boundary point that is included in an existing boundary that defines a new primary parcel if all of the following are true:
- it is practicable for the mark to be placed at the boundary point
- the boundary defines a parcel that is part of a Hawkes Bay interim title
- one of the survey purposes is an application to make the Hawkes Bay interim title conclusive.

Signifier: Boundary mark on new boundary point
Statement: Boundary mark on new boundary point
column4:
A mark need not be placed at a new boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a new primary parcel if any the following are true:
- all parcels that are adjacent to the boundary point are new parcels intended to be owned by the Crown
- all parcels that are adjacent to the boundary point are new parcels intended to be owned by the same territorial authority
- the Maori Land Court does not require a mark to be placed at a boundary point that is included in the boundary
- all parcels that are adjacent to the boundary point are or will be held in common ownership
- the parcels on each side of the boundary are or will be subject to a reciprocal right of way
- the terrain, ground cover, or protected vegetation make it unlikely that the boundary point will need to be physically located
- the boundary point results from an existing water or irregular boundary being converted to a right-line boundary that is a class B boundary
- the boundary point coincides with a water boundary
- the boundary point coincides with a water centre-line boundary
- it is not practicable for a mark to be placed at the boundary point.

Signifier: Boundary mark on parcel that is limited as to parcels
Statement: Boundary mark on parcel that is limited as to parcels
column4: A boundary mark must not be placed at a boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a parcel that is limited as to parcels.

Signifier: Boundary mark reference to permanent reference mark
Statement: Boundary mark reference to permanent reference mark
column4: A referenced boundary mark must be referenced by a permanent reference mark.
A boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is coincident with a boundary if the boundary point is intended to lie on the line of the boundary.

Signifier: Boundary point reference to permanent reference mark
Statement: Boundary point reference to permanent reference mark
column4: A referenced boundary point must be referenced by a permanent reference mark.

Signifier: Boundary point reference to PRM Class A
Statement: Boundary point reference to PRM Class A
column4:
A class A boundary point must be less than or equal to 150 m from a permanent reference mark if any of the following is true:
- the boundary point is a referenced boundary point
- the boundary point is a referenced boundary mark
- the boundary point is a referenced height-limited boundary point
- the boundary point is a boundary mark that is included in a boundary defining a non-primary parcel
- the boundary point is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel and is not accurately related to a boundary defining an underlying parcel
- the boundary point is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel that overlies a parcel that is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake.

Signifier: Boundary point reference to PRM Class B
Statement: Boundary point reference to PRM Class B
column4:
A class B boundary point must be less than or equal to 500 m from a permanent reference mark if any of the following is true:
- the boundary point is a referenced boundary point
- the boundary point is a referenced boundary mark
- the boundary point is a referenced height-limited boundary point
- the boundary point is a boundary mark that is included in a boundary defining a non-primary parcel
- the boundary point is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel and is not accurately related to a boundary defining an underlying parcel
- the boundary point is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel that overlies a parcel that is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake.

Signifier: Boundary point reference to PRM Class C
Statement: Boundary point reference to PRM Class C
column4:
A class C boundary point must be less than or equal to 1000 m from a permanent reference mark if any of the following is true:
- the boundary point is a referenced boundary point
- the boundary point is a referenced boundary mark
- the boundary point is a referenced height-limited boundary point.

An existing centre-line easement parcel need not be represented as a polygon or polyhedron only if any of the following is true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the width of the centre-line easement is unknown\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the centre-line easement is an accepted boundary.
A CSD must be certified and dated by a cadastral surveyor as follows:\u003Cbr/\u003E\nI [name]
column6: certify that—\u003Cbr/\u003E\n(a) this dataset provided by me and its related survey are accurate
column8: and in accordance with the Cadastral Survey Act 2002 and the Cadastral Survey Rules 2020; and\u003Cbr/\u003E\n(b) the survey was undertaken by me or under my personal direction.""

column4: An accuracy [relative] between a boundary point and another boundary point must be considered a class A accuracy only if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- The accuracy [relative] is less than or equal to 0.06 + (0.00015 * the horizontal distance between the boundary points)\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- The accuracy [relative] is less than or equal to 0.06 + (0.00015 * the slope distance between the boundary points).

A boundary must be considered a class A boundary if any of the following are true:
- the boundary is in an urban area
- the boundary is adjoining an urban area
- the boundary is intended as a result of a cadastral survey to be in an urban area
- the boundary defines a parcel that is used intensively for commercial, industrial, or residential purposes
- the boundary defines a parcel that is intended as a result of a cadastral survey to be used intensively for commercial, industrial, or residential purposes.
A boundary point must be considered a class A boundary point if the boundary point is included in a class A boundary.

An accuracy [relative] between a boundary point and another boundary point must be considered a class B accuracy only if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- The accuracy [relative] is less than or equal to 0.30 + (0.0006 * the horizontal distance between the boundary points)\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- The accuracy [relative] is less than or equal to 0.30 + (0.0006 * the slope distance between the boundary points).

A boundary must be considered a class B boundary if the boundary is not any of the following:
- a class A boundary
- a class C boundary
- a class D boundary.

A boundary point must be considered a class B boundary point if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary point is not included in a class A boundary\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary point is included in a class B boundary.

Signifier: Class B non-primary parcel boundary permitted inaccurate relationship to underlying parcel
Statement: Class B non-primary parcel boundary permitted inaccurate relationship to underlying parcel
column4:
A boundary that defines a non-primary parcel may be not accurately related to another boundary that defines a primary parcel that underlies the non-primary parcel in a cadastral survey only if the primary parcel is not created by that cadastral survey and any of the following are true:
- the boundary is a class b boundary
- the other boundary is a class b boundary
- none of the boundaries that define the primary parcel are accurately defined boundaries.

An accuracy [relative] between a boundary point and another boundary point must be considered a class C accuracy only if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- The accuracy [relative] is less than or equal to 1.00 + (0.003 * the horizontal distance between the boundary points)\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- The accuracy [relative] is less than or equal to 1.00 + (0.003 * the slope distance between the boundary points).

A boundary that defines a primary parcel must be a class C boundary only if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is an adopted boundary\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is not a class A boundary.

A boundary must not be considered a class C boundary if all of the following are false:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary defines a majority successor parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary defines a new large rural parcel.

A boundary must not be considered a class C boundary if all of the following are false:
- an accuracy [relative] between boundary points that are included in the boundary is not class B accuracy
- the boundary defines a parcel that is included in a title that is to remain limited as to parcels
- the boundary defines a parcel that is included in a title that is to remain a Hawkes Bay interim title.

A boundary point must be considered a class C boundary point if all of the following are true:
- the boundary point is not included in a class A boundary
- the boundary point is not included in a class B boundary
- the boundary point is included in a class C boundary.

Signifier: Class C for common marine and coastal area
Statement: Class C for common marine and coastal area
column4: A boundary defining a non-primary parcel may be a class C boundary only if the non-primary parcel is within the common marine and coastal area.

The relationship between a non-primary parcel and the underlying primary parcel may be inaccurately determined only if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the non-primary parcel is an easement parcel or covenant parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundaries that define the non-primary parcel are class C boundaries.
A boundary must be considered a class D boundary if the boundary is an accepted boundary.

A boundary point must be considered a class D boundary point if all of the following are true:
- the boundary point is not included in a class A boundary
- the boundary point is not included in a class B boundary
- the boundary point is not included in a class C boundary
- the boundary point is included in a class D boundary.
A parcel that is a movable marginal strip included in a CSD must be depicted on a title diagram as being contained within the underlying primary parcel of the movable marginal strip.

A boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a new primary parcel must be connected to a cadastral survey network mark that is less than and equal to 1,000m from the boundary point by a series of vectors that consists only of vectors that are adopted or measured if any of the following is true:
- the boundary point is a new boundary point
- the boundary point is a new boundary mark
- the boundary point is a old boundary mark.

A boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a new primary parcel may be connected to only cadastral survey network marks that are more than 1,000m from the boundary point only if all of the following are true:
- there are no existing cadastral survey network marks that are less than or equal to 1,000m from the boundary point
- the boundary point is connected to the cadastral survey network marks by a series of vectors that consists only of vectors that are adopted or measured
- the boundary point is a new boundary point or a new boundary mark or a old boundary mark.

Signifier: Content of simple boundary reinstatement CSD
Statement: Content of simple boundary reinstatement CSD
column4:
A simple boundary reinstatement CSD must include all of the following:
- a record of survey
- a survey report
- a dataset description that includes the survey purpose and the legal description of the parcel whose boundary is being reinstated
- a statement of certification.

Signifier: CSD number for unit title development
Statement: CSD number for unit title development
column4: A CSD for a unit title development that is deposited must retain the same CSD number as the previously deposited CSD that the CSD is substituted for.

A CSD must comply with the cadastral survey rules when in providing data about the following:
- a bearing
- a distance
- a reduced level
- an area [quantity].

Signifier: Definition of existing boundary point being marked
Statement: Definition of existing boundary point being marked
column4: An existing boundary point that has a new mark being placed at the boundary point must be defined by survey.

Signifier: Definition of existing boundary point required to be marked
Statement: Definition of existing boundary point required to be marked
column4:
A boundary point that is included in an existing boundary that defines a new primary parcel must be defined by survey if any of the following are true:
- the boundary point is subject to conflict
- the boundary point is included in an existing boundary that is defined in an approved CSD where the definition of the existing boundary is insufficient for determining the compliance of the boundary with the applicable accuracy standard
- the boundary point is included in an existing boundary that is only defined in a diagram on transfer
- the boundary point is included in an existing boundary that defines a parcel from which limitation as to parcels is being uplifted
- the boundary point is included in an existing boundary of a parcel from which the interim nature of the Hawkes Bay interim title is being removed
- the boundary point is included in an existing boundary of a parcel that is subject to a claim for adverse possession
- the boundary point is recorded in a Maori land CSD that is annotated computed plan-areas and boundaries not defined by survey"
- the boundary point was an unmarked boundary point that is included in a boundary defining a non-primary parcel."
A new boundary point must be defined by survey.
A new irregular boundary must be defined by survey.
A new water boundary must be defined by survey.

Signifier: Definition of right line boundary replacing irregular, water or water centreline boundary
Statement: Definition of right line boundary replacing irregular, water or water centreline boundary
column4: A new right-line boundary must be defined by survey if the right-line boundary converts a water or irregular boundary.

Signifier: Derivation of accurate relation of boundaries
Statement: Derivation of accurate relation of boundaries
column4: A boundary may be considered a boundary accurately related to another boundary only if the boundary consists of boundary points that are all accurately related to each boundary point that is included in the other boundary.
A boundary must be considered a boundary that is accurately defined only if each boundary point that is included in the boundary is an accurately defined boundary point.

Signifier: Derivation of affected by ground movement
Statement: Derivation of affected by ground movement
column4:
A boundary must be considered to be affected by ground movement if all of the following are true:
- ground movement has distorted land crossed by the boundary in excess of the tolerance for the accuracy class relevant to the boundary
- the boundary has not been subsequently defined by survey and recorded in an approved CSD.

- is it better to rename the concept to 'boundary affected by ground movement'

Signifier: Derivation of boundary point is subject to conflict
Statement: Derivation of boundary point is subject to conflict
column4: A boundary point must be considered a boundary point subject to conflict if the boundary point is included in a boundary subject to conflict.

Signifier: Derivation of class A accurate relation of boundary points
Statement: Derivation of class A accurate relation of boundary points
column4: A class A boundary point must be considered a boundary point accurately related to another class A boundary point only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary points is class A accuracy.

Signifier: Derivation of class A boundary is subject to accuracy conflict with estate boundary
Statement: Derivation of class A boundary is subject to accuracy conflict with estate boundary
column4: A class A boundary that is recorded in an approved CSD must be considered a boundary subject to conflict if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the accuracy [relative] between a boundary point that is included in the boundary and another boundary point that is included in an estate boundary that coincides with the boundary is not class A\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the conflict is not resolved in another approved CSD.

Signifier: Derivation of class A boundary is subject to position conflict with estate boundary
Statement: Derivation of class A boundary is subject to position conflict with estate boundary
column4: A class A boundary recorded in an approved CSD must be considered a boundary subject to conflict if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the accuracy [relative] between boundary points that are included in the boundary is not class A when other approved CSDs that record the boundary are taken into consideration\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the conflict is not resolved in another approved CSD.

Signifier: Derivation of class B accurate relation of boundary points
Statement: Derivation of class B accurate relation of boundary points
column4: A class B boundary point must be considered a boundary point accurately related to another boundary point only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary points is class B accuracy when the other boundary point is any of:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- a class A boundary point\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- a class B boundary point.

Signifier: Derivation of class B boundary is subject to conflict with estate boundary
Statement: Derivation of class B boundary is subject to conflict with estate boundary
column4: A class B boundary must be considered a boundary subject to conflict if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is an existing boundary\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the accuracy [relative] between a boundary point that is included in the boundary and a boundary point that is included in an estate boundary that coincides with the boundary is not class B.

Signifier: Derivation of class C accurate relation of boundary points
Statement: Derivation of class C accurate relation of boundary points
column4:
A class C boundary point must be considered a boundary point accurately related to another boundary point only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary points is class C accuracy when the other boundary point is any of:
- a class A boundary point
- a class B boundary point
- a class C boundary point.

Signifier: Derivation of class C boundary is subject to conflict with estate boundary
Statement: Derivation of class C boundary is subject to conflict with estate boundary
column4: A class C boundary must be considered a boundary subject to conflict if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is an existing boundary\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the accuracy [relative] between a boundary point that is included in the boundary and a boundary point that is included in an estate boundary that coincides with the boundary is not class C.

Signifier: Derivation of class D accurate relation of boundary points
Statement: Derivation of class D accurate relation of boundary points
column4: A class D boundary point must be considered a boundary point accurately related to another boundary point only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary points is class D accuracy.

Signifier: Derivation of class D boundary is subject to conflict with estate boundary
Statement: Derivation of class D boundary is subject to conflict with estate boundary
column4: A class D boundary must be considered a boundary subject to conflict if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is an existing boundary\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the accuracy [relative] between a boundary point that is included in the boundary and a boundary point that is included in an estate boundary that coincides with the boundary is not class D.
A CSD must be considered a complete CSD only if the CSD consists of a record of survey.
A CSD for a cadastral survey that creates a parcel must be considered a complete CSD only if the CSD consists of a title plan.
A CSD must be considered a complete CSD only if the CSD consists of a dataset description.
A CSD must be considered a complete CSD only if the CSD consists of a survey report.
A CSD must be considered a complete CSD only if the CSD consists of all relevant field information related to that CSD in a form that ensures permanent usability.
A CSD must be considered a complete CSD only if the CSD includes an accurate record of the position of each new water boundary that is in that CSD.
A CSD must be considered a complete CSD only if the CSD includes a certification of survey plan approval if the CSD is for a Crown subdivision.
A dataset description included in a CSD must have a parcel ID for each primary parcel that is created by the cadastral survey.
A dataset description included in a CSD must have the survey purpose if the CSD is a land transfer CSD.
A dataset description included in a CSD must have a parcel ID for each underlying parcel in that CSD if the CSD is a land transfer CSD.

An existing parcel must be considered an extinguished parcel if any of the following is true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the existing parcel has been replaced by at least one new parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the existing parcel has expired.
A boundary mark must be considered a referenced boundary mark if the boundary mark is included in a boundary that defines a parcel being surveyed.

A boundary point that is defined by survey and is included in a boundary that defines a primary parcel must be considered a referenced boundary point if the boundary is not a water or irregular boundary.
A point must be considered a point that is referenced by a permanent reference mark only if at least one series of vectors connects the point and the permanent reference mark.

Signifier: Derivation of referenced height-limited boundary point
Statement: Derivation of referenced height-limited boundary point
column4: A new boundary point must be considered a referenced height-limited boundary point if the boundary point is included in a height limited boundary that defines a primary parcel.

Signifier: Derivation of right area non-primary parcel
Statement: Derivation of right area non-primary parcel
column4: Only a right area that is in the common marine and coastal area may be a right area that is a category of non-primary parcel

Signifier: Destroyed or not found survey mark
Statement: Destroyed or not found survey mark
column4: A record of survey must identify whether a survey mark is any of the following:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- searched for and not found\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- destroyed.
A disturbed survey mark may be driven below the surface if the survey mark is categorized only as a boundary mark.
A disturbed survey mark may be removed if the survey mark is categorized only as a boundary mark.
A survey mark must be considered a new survey mark the same survey mark type as the old survey mark if the survey mark is a disturbed survey mark.

Signifier: Easement or covenant accuracy between boundary point and adopted CSNM
Statement: Easement or covenant accuracy between boundary point and adopted CSNM
column4: The accuracy [relative] between a boundary point that defines a boundary of a non-primary parcel and a cadastral survey network mark must be less than or equal to 0.6 m if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the non-primary parcel is an easement parcel or a covenant parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is not a class D boundary.

Signifier: Easement or covenant connected by vectors to CSNM
Statement: Easement or covenant connected by vectors to CSNM
column4: A boundary point that defines a boundary of a non-primary parcel must be connected by vectors to at least 1 cadastral survey network mark if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the non-primary parcel is an easement parcel or a covenant parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is not a class D boundary.
A record of survey must include the type of equipment used in the field measurement of each measured vector in the cadastral survey.

Signifier: Existing boundary defining new large rural parcel being accepted
Statement: Existing boundary defining new large rural parcel being accepted
column4: An existing boundary that defines a new large rural parcel may be an accepted boundary only if any other new parcel defined by the boundary is a new large rural parcel.

Signifier: Existing irregular boundary on a new primary parcel
Statement: Existing irregular boundary on a new primary parcel
column4:
A new primary parcel may be defined by an existing irregular boundary only if any of the following are true:
- the irregular boundary is an accepted boundary
- the primary parcel is a majority successor parcel
- the primary parcel is a large rural parcel
- the irregular boundary was previously a water boundary.

Signifier: Existing irregular boundary on a parcel
Statement: Existing irregular boundary on a parcel
column4: An existing irregular boundary that defines a parcel must be converted to right-line boundaries.
The name of an existing survey mark that is not unique in a CSD must be made unique by adding a unique numeric identifier within round brackets before the CSD number.

Signifier: Existing unit and lease boundaries accepted
Statement: Existing unit and lease boundaries accepted
column4:
The boundaries of an existing unit parcel may be accepted only if all of the following are true:
- the existing parcel is included in an approved CSD
- no change is made to any parcel boundary
- no change is made to the record of title of the parcel.

Signifier: Existing unit and lease boundaries accepted 2
Statement: Existing unit and lease boundaries accepted 2
column4:
The boundaries of an existing company lease parcel may be accepted only if all of the following are true:
- the existing parcel is included in an approved CSD
- no change is made to any parcel boundary
- no change is made to the record of title of the parcel.

Signifier: Existing unit and lease boundaries accepted 3
Statement: Existing unit and lease boundaries accepted 3
column4:
The boundaries of an existing cross lease parcel may be accepted only if all of the following are true:
- the existing parcel is included in an approved CSD
- no change is made to any parcel boundary
- no change is made to the record of title of the parcel.

Signifier: Existing unit and lease boundary parcel appellation
Statement: Existing unit and lease boundary parcel appellation
column4:
The existing parcel appellation of all of the following must be retained if the boundaries of the parcel are accepted:
- an existing unit parcel
- an existing company lease parcel
- an existing cross lease parcel.
The font size for an appellation and area must be significantly larger than the font size used for vectors, dimensions, descriptions, and survey mark information.

An existing water boundary for which the margin of the water body has moved by processes other than accretion or erosion must be adopted as an irregular boundary or converted to one or more right-line boundaries.
A height limited boundary must be a surface that is mathematically described if any boundary point that is included in the boundary has a reduced level.
A height limited boundary must be a surface of a water body or the bed of a water body if no boundary point that is included in the boundary has a reduced level.

Signifier: Height limited boundary point referenced to PRM
Statement: Height limited boundary point referenced to PRM
column4: A referenced height-limited boundary point must be referenced by a permanent reference mark that has a reduced level.

Signifier: Height limited boundary points on unit development
Statement: Height limited boundary points on unit development
column4: The reduced levels in a unit title development must be expressed in terms of the previously deposited CSD for that unit title development.

Signifier: Height limited boundary points on unit development 2
Statement: Height limited boundary points on unit development 2
column4: A vertical control mark that is less than or equal to 1,000 m from a new height limited boundary point in a unit title development must be provided with a reduced level in terms of the unit title development if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- there is at least one vertical control mark less than or equal to 1,000 m from the boundary point\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- an unofficial datum is used in a cadastral survey for the unit title development.

Signifier: Height limited boundary points on unit development 3
Statement: Height limited boundary points on unit development 3
column4: A vertical control mark that is more than 1,000 m from a new height limited boundary point in a unit title development must be provided with a reduced level in terms of a unit title development if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- there are no vertical control marks that are less than or equal to 1,000 m from the boundary point\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- an unofficial datum is used in a cadastral survey for the unit title development.

Signifier: Horizontal accuracy between adopted Cadastral Survey Network Mark and non-boundary mark 1
Statement: Horizontal accuracy between adopted Cadastral Survey Network Mark and non-boundary mark 1
column4: The accuracy [relative] between an adopted cadastral survey network mark and each non-boundary mark must not exceed 0.025 + (0.00015 * the horizontal distance between the adopted cadastral survey network mark and the non-boundary mark).

Signifier: Horizontal accuracy between adopted Cadastral Survey Network Mark and non-boundary mark 2
Statement: Horizontal accuracy between adopted Cadastral Survey Network Mark and non-boundary mark 2
column4: The accuracy [relative] between an adopted cadastral survey network mark and each non-boundary mark must not exceed 0.2 m horizontal.
The accuracy [relative] between a non-boundary mark and each other non-boundary mark must not exceed 0.025 + (0.00005 * the horizontal distance between the non-boundary marks).
The accuracy [relative] between a non-boundary mark and each other non-boundary mark must not exceed 0.2 m horizontal.

Signifier: Horizontal Class A accuracy of boundary referencing
Statement: Horizontal Class A accuracy of boundary referencing
column4: A class A boundary point that is a referenced point must be considered an accurately defined boundary point only if the accuracy [relative] between the class A boundary point and each non-boundary mark that is less than or equal to 150 m from the class A boundary point does not exceed 0.03 m horizontal.

Signifier: Horizontal Class B accuracy of boundary referencing
Statement: Horizontal Class B accuracy of boundary referencing
column4: A class B boundary point that is a referenced point must be considered an accurately defined boundary point only if the accuracy [relative] between the class B boundary point and each non-boundary mark that is less than or equal to 500 m from the class B boundary point does not exceed 0.20 m horizontal.

Signifier: Horizontal Class C accuracy of boundary referencing
Statement: Horizontal Class C accuracy of boundary referencing
column4: A class C boundary point that is a referenced point must be considered an accurately defined boundary point only if the accuracy [relative] between the class C boundary point and each non-boundary mark that is less than or equal to 1000 m from the class C boundary point does not exceed 0.60 m horizontal.

Signifier: Horizontal connection for non-primary parcels over water 1
Statement: Horizontal connection for non-primary parcels over water 1
column4: A boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel must be connected by at least one vector to a cadastral survey network mark if the underlying parcel is a common marine and coastal area.

Signifier: Horizontal connection for non-primary parcels over water 2
Statement: Horizontal connection for non-primary parcels over water 2
column4: An accuracy [relative] between a boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel and an adopted cadastral survey network mark must not exceed 0.60 m horizontal if the underlying parcel is a common marine and coastal area.

Signifier: Horizontal extent of a primary parcel
Statement: Horizontal extent of a primary parcel
column4:
The horizontal extent of a primary parcel must be defined by only the following:
- a right-line boundary
- an arc boundary
- a water or irregular boundary.

The horizontal extent of a non-primary parcel must be defined by only the following:
- a right-line boundary
- an arc boundary
- a water or irregular boundary
- a permanent structure boundary.

Signifier: Impracticable to mark boundary point record
Statement: Impracticable to mark boundary point record
column4: A record of survey must identify a boundary point as impracticable to mark if it is impracticable to mark the boundary point.

A record of survey must include all of the following:
- a survey diagram
- a list of all CSDs used in the survey
- the identity of any parcel that is to be extinguished.
- the dataset description
- a statement of certification.
A record of survey must include the land district of each CSD used in the survey if the CSD number of each CSD is not unique.
A record of survey must include the date the survey was completed if a field measurement is made in the survey.

A record of survey must include all of the following on every sheet of the record of survey:
- the CSD number
- the sheet number
- the total number of sheets in the record of survey.
An existing irregular boundary need not be converted to right-line boundaries if the parcels defined by the boundary are non-primary parcels.
A boundary that defines a non-primary parcel must be an irregular boundary if the boundary coincides with an irregular boundary that defines a movable marginal strip or defines an esplanade strip.

Signifier: Labeling a balance parcel in a CSD
Statement: Labeling a balance parcel in a CSD
column4: A parcel ID of a balance parcel in a CSD must consist of the prefix Part" added to the parcel ID of the existing parcel that is extinguished when the balance parcel is created."

Signifier: Labeling a new parcel of land
Statement: Labeling a new parcel of land
column4:
A parcel ID of a new parcel in a CSD must consist of the following components in the listed sequence:
- a parcel type component
- a unique parcel identifier
- the CSD number
if the parcel is not any of the following:
- a new parcel described as a Maori freehold land
- a balance parcel
- a residue parcel.

Signifier: Labeling a proposed unit formerly created in a CSD
Statement: Labeling a proposed unit formerly created in a CSD
column4: The parcel ID of a proposed unit created under a previous legislation must be retained.

Signifier: Labeling a residue parcel in a CSD
Statement: Labeling a residue parcel in a CSD
column4:
A parcel ID of a residue parcel in a CSD must consist of the prefix Part" added to the parcel ID of the existing parcel if the other portion of the existing parcel has been described as any of the following:
- the bed of a lake
- the bed of a river
- part of the common marine and coastal area."

Signifier: Labelling a new parcel of Maori land
Statement: Labelling a new parcel of Maori land
column4:
A parcel ID for a new parcel described as a Maori freehold land in a CSD must consist of the following components in the listed sequence:
- a block name or an alternative legal description confirmed by the Maori Land Court
- a unique parcel identifier or an alternative legal description confirmed by the Maori Land Court
- the CSD number.

Signifier: Land value and water or irregular boundaries
Statement: Land value and water or irregular boundaries
column4: A water or irregular boundary that is not an accepted boundary must have its position determined to a level of accuracy [positional] that takes into account for each parcel that is defined by the boundary all of the following:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the value of the land\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the intensity of the land use.

The styles and widths in table 9 of Schedule 7 of RCS 2020 must be used for lines in a diagram plan. When a line serves more than one purpose, a style higher up the table takes precedence over a style below it. The width of a thick line must be at least twice the width of a thin line.

Signifier: Minimum PRMs in a cadastral survey
Statement: Minimum PRMs in a cadastral survey
column4:
A cadastral survey must include at least 3 permanent reference marks.

========================

A cadastral survey must include at least 3 permanent reference marks for which any of the following is true:
- the permanent reference mark is not more than 150 m from a referenced point that is a class a boundary point
- the permanent reference mark is not more than 500 m from a referenced point that is a class b boundary point
- the permanent reference mark is not more than 1000m from a referenced point that is a class c boundary point.

Signifier: Minimum width of a new primary parcel with class A boundaries
Statement: Minimum width of a new primary parcel with class A boundaries
column4:
A new primary parcel must be greater than or equal to 0.1 m wide if all of the following are true:
- the boundaries that define the primary parcel are class A boundaries
- the primary parcel is not a balance parcel
- the primary parcel is not a residue parcel.

Signifier: Minimum width of a new primary parcel with class B, C or D boundaries
Statement: Minimum width of a new primary parcel with class B, C or D boundaries
column4:
A new primary parcel must be greater than or equal to 0.2 m wide if all of the following are true:
- the boundaries that define the primary parcel are not class A boundaries
- the primary parcel is not a balance parcel
- the primary parcel is not a residue parcel.

Signifier: Movement of water body margin and water or irregular boundaries
Statement: Movement of water body margin and water or irregular boundaries
column4: A water or irregular boundary that is not an accepted boundary must have its position determined to a level of accuracy [positional] that allows for the potential for the boundary to move or become permanent as a result of movement of the margin of a water body that adjoins the boundary.
A new point in a CSD must have a point name that consists of a unique alphanumeric identifier followed by the CSD number.

A new survey point in a CSD that is unmarked must have a name that consists of all the following components in the listed sequence:
- the abbreviation 'UNMK'
- a unique alphanumeric identifier
- the CSD number.

A new survey mark in a CSD must have a mark name that consists of all the following components in the listed sequence:
- an abbreviation describing the physical mark type
- a unique alphanumeric identifier
- the CSD number.

A new boundary mark must be one of the following if practicable:
- a wooden peg that is chamfered at the top and has a minimum width of 45 mm and is at least 3000 square mm in cross-section
- a type of peg that is not a wooden peg and is clearly labelled as a boundary mark
- a post
- a mark in a post which is clearly labelled as a boundary mark.

A new boundary mark must be any other type of mark clearly labeled as a boundary mark if it is not practicable to be any of the following:
- a wooden peg that is chamfered at the top and has a minimum width of 45 mm and is at least 3000 square mm in cross-section
- a type of peg that is not a wooden peg and is clearly labelled as a boundary mark
- a post
- a mark in a post which is clearly labelled as a boundary mark.
A new boundary mark must be soundly anchored in place.
A new boundary mark must be readily visible if practicable.
A new boundary mark must be placed at a boundary point.

Signifier: New primary parcel created in a CSD 1
Statement: New primary parcel created in a CSD 1
column4:
An existing primary parcel being extinguished by a new primary parcel must have all land in the existing primary parcel included in at least one of the following:
- one or more new primary parcels
- a residue parcel
- a balance parcel.

Signifier: New primary parcel created in a CSD 2
Statement: New primary parcel created in a CSD 2
column4:
An existing primary parcel being extinguished by a new primary parcel that is defined by a height limited boundary must have all space occupied by the existing primary parcel included in at least one of the following:
- one or more new primary parcels
- a residue parcel
- a balance parcel.

A boundary that defines a non-primary parcel and coincides with another boundary defining an underlying parcel must be an accepted boundary if any of the following is true:
- the boundary is not accurately related to the other boundary
- the underlying parcel is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake
- the boundary is a class c boundary.

A boundary that defines a non-primary parcel must be the same boundary form as a boundary that defines an underlying parcel if the boundary that defines the non-primary parcel coincides with the boundary that defines the underlying parcel.
A mark need not be placed at a new boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel.

A boundary that defines a non-primary parcel and intersects with another boundary defining an underlying parcel must be a class D boundary if any of the following is true:
- the boundary is not accurately related to the other boundary
- the underlying parcel is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake
- the boundary is a class c boundary.

The boundaries that define a non-primary parcel may be accurately related to only some of the boundaries that define an underlying parcel only if the other boundaries that define the underlying parcel are all class d boundaries.

A non-primary parcel boundary must be a class D boundary and the accuracy [relative] of the boundary points must be class D if all of the following are true:
- the relationship of the non-primary parcel boundary points are not accurately determined
- the underlying parcel is a new parcel
- the non-primary parcel boundary intersects or the non-primary parcel boundary coincides with an accepted boundary of the underlying parcel.

A boundary point must be referenced by a permanent reference mark if the boundary point is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel and any of the following is true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is not a class D boundary and the boundary is not accurately related to a boundary defining an underlying parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the non-primary parcel overlies a parcel that is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake.

The horizontal projection used in a cadastral survey must be an official geodetic projection applicable to the area that the cadastral survey is carried out in if the cadastral survey includes a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel and any of the following is true:
- the boundary is not accurately related to a boundary defining an underlying parcel.
- the non-primary parcel overlies a parcel that is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake
- the boundary is a class c boundary.

Signifier: Non-primary parcel with inaccurate relationship to new primary parcel
Statement: Non-primary parcel with inaccurate relationship to new primary parcel
column4: The accuracy [positional] of a non-primary parcel boundary point may be inaccurately determined only if the underlying parcel is a new parcel and any of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the non-primary parcel boundary intersects with an accepted boundary of the underlying parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the non-primary parcel boundary coincides with an accepted boundary of the underlying parcel.
A non-primary parcel may cross a boundary only if the boundary is not an estate boundary.

A geodetic projection must be considered an official geodetic projection if it is any of the following NZGD2000 Transverse Mercator 2000 meridional circuit projections:
- Mount Eden 2000
- Bay of Plenty 2000
- Poverty Bay 2000
- Hawkes Bay 2000
- Taranaki 2000
- Tuhirangi 2000
- Wanganui 2000
- Wairarapa 2000
- Wellington 2000
- Collingwood 2000
- Nelson 2000
- Karamea 2000
- Buller 2000
- Grey 2000
- Amuri 2000
- Marlborough 2000
- Hokitika 2000
- Okarito 2000
- Jacksons Bay 2000
- Mount Pleasant 2000
- Gawler 2000
- Timaru 2000
- Lindis Peak 2000
- Mount Nicholas 2000
- Mount York 2000
- Observation Point 2000
- North Taieri 2000
- Bluff 2000.

A official vertical datum must be any of the following:
- New Zealand Vertical Datum 2016 or NZVD2016
- One Tree Point 1964
- Auckland 1946
- Moturiki 1953
- Gisborne 1926
- Napier 1962
- Taranaki 1970
- Wellington 1953
- Nelson 1955
- Lyttelton 1937
- Dunedin 1958
- Dunedin – Bluff 1960
- Bluff 1955
- Stewart Island 1977.

A new water boundary that defines a non-primary parcel may be offset from an accepted water boundary only when the new water boundary is at MHWS or MLWS and the non-primary parcel is over any of the following bodies of water:
- a stream
- a river
- a lake
- a common marine and coastal area.
The bearing of each vector in a cadastral survey must be oriented in terms of the same horizontal projection.

The horizontal projection used in a cadastral survey must be an official geodetic projection applicable to the area that the cadastral survey is carried out in if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the cadastral survey defines or marks a new boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a primary parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the cadastral survey makes a new field measurement.
An area [quantity] must be assigned to a parcel that is intended for a lease if the parcel is not defined by any permanent structure boundaries.
An area [quantity] assigned to a parcel that has a shape that varies with height must equal the area [quantity] of the horizontal extent of the parcel.
An area [quantity] assigned to a parcel must be correctly calculated from boundary information of the parcel.
An area [quantity] assigned to a parcel must be expressed in hectares.
An area [quantity] assigned to a parcel must not be less than 0.0001 ha.
An area [quantity] assigned to a parcel may be rounded only to the greater of one part in 1000 of the area [quantity] or 0.0001 ha.
An area [quantity] assigned to a primary parcel must include the area [quantity] assigned to each movable marginal strip in that primary parcel.
A parcel type component must be determined according to the parcel type component table.
A permanent structure boundary must follow a described part of a permanent structure or be clearly defined by reference to points on the interior or exterior of a permanent structure.

A permanent structure boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary point and each boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines the same parcel that the permanent structure is on is class A accuracy when the boundary points are both class A boundary points.

A permanent structure boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary point and each boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines the same parcel that the permanent structure is on is class B accuracy when one of the boundary points is a class B boundary point and the other is any of:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- a class A boundary point\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- a class B boundary point.

A permanent structure boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary point and each boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines the same parcel that the permanent structure is on is class C accuracy when one of the boundary points is a class C boundary point and the other is any of:
- a class A boundary point
- a class B boundary point
- a class C boundary point.

A permanent structure boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the boundary point and each boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines the same parcel that the permanent structure is on is class D accuracy when one of the boundary points is a class D boundary point.

A permanent structure boundary may define a parcel intended for a right under the Unit Titles Act 2010 only if any of the parcels underlying the unit title development and any part the permanent structure are the same irrelevant of the permanent structure encroaching onto an adjoining parcel.

A permanent structure boundary may define a parcel intended for a lease for which the boundary is located by reference to the permanent structure only if any of the parcels underlying the lease and any part the permanent structure are the same irrelevant of the permanent structure encroaching onto an adjoining parcel.\u003Cbr/\u003E\n\u003Cbr/\u003E\nA permanent structure boundary may define a parcel intended for a lease only if any part of the permanent structure that locates by reference the boundary is located on the same parcel that underlies that lease.

A permanent structure boundary may define a parcel intended for a right over or an appurtenant to a base right under the Unit Titles Act 2010 or a base lease for which the boundary is located by reference to the permanent structure only if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the right will expire before or at the same time as the base right or base lease\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- any of the parcels underlying the base right or the base lease and any part the permanent structure are the same.

A permanent structure boundary may define an easement parcel or a covenant parcel only if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the use of the easement parcel or covenant parcel is directly related to the permanent structure\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the easement or covenant is expected to become redundant once the permanent structure ceases to exist.

Signifier: Permanent structure boundary point class A horizontal accuracy
Statement: Permanent structure boundary point class A horizontal accuracy
column4: A permanent structure boundary point that is a class A boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the permanent structure boundary point and each point on the permanent structure does not exceed 0.03 m horizontal.

Signifier: Permanent structure boundary point class A vertical accuracy
Statement: Permanent structure boundary point class A vertical accuracy
column4: A permanent structure boundary point that is a class A boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the permanent structure boundary point and each point on the permanent structure does not exceed 0.04 m vertical.

Signifier: Permanent structure boundary point class B horizontal accuracy
Statement: Permanent structure boundary point class B horizontal accuracy
column4: A permanent structure boundary point that is a class B boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the permanent structure boundary point and each point on the permanent structure does not exceed 0.2 m horizontal.

Signifier: Permanent structure boundary point class B vertical accuracy
Statement: Permanent structure boundary point class B vertical accuracy
column4: A permanent structure boundary point that is a class B boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the permanent structure boundary point and each point on the permanent structure does not exceed 0.2 m vertical.

Signifier: Permanent structure boundary point class C horizontal accuracy
Statement: Permanent structure boundary point class C horizontal accuracy
column4: A permanent structure boundary point that is a class C boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the permanent structure boundary point and each point on the permanent structure does not exceed 0.6 m horizontal.

Signifier: Permanent structure boundary point class C vertical accuracy
Statement: Permanent structure boundary point class C vertical accuracy
column4: A permanent structure boundary point that is a class C boundary point must be considered a boundary point that is accurately defined only if the accuracy [relative] between the permanent structure boundary point and each point on the permanent structure does not exceed 0.6 m vertical.

Signifier: Physical feature water or irregular boundaries
Statement: Physical feature water or irregular boundaries
column4: A water or irregular boundary that is not an accepted boundary must have its position determined to a level of accuracy [positional] that takes into account the nature of any physical feature that defines the margin of a water body that adjoins the boundary.
An area [quantity] must be assigned to a primary parcel if the primary parcel is not any of the following:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- a residue parcel\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- a balance parcel.
A principal unit must contain a building or be part of a building or be contained within a building or be a car park.
A record of survey must describe the relationship of any permanent reference mark to ground level and the situation of the permanent reference mark.

Signifier: Record of Survey Accepted Boundary Points
Statement: Record of Survey Accepted Boundary Points
column4: A record of survey need not include accepted boundary points used for the purposes of the cadastral survey.

A record of survey must include the accuracy class of all of the following included in the record of survey:
- a right-line boundary
- an arc boundary
- a height limited boundary.
A record of survey must include the meridional circuit projection of the survey area if a bearing is included in the record of survey.
A record of survey must include the vertical datum if a reduced level is recorded in the record of survey.

Signifier: Record of survey for simple boundary reinstatement CSD
Statement: Record of survey for simple boundary reinstatement CSD
column4:
A record of survey for a simple boundary reinstatement survey must include all of the following:
- a reinstatement diagram
- a list of CSDs used and, if a CSD number is not unique, the land district of the CSD
- the date the cadastral survey was completed
- datum information in accordance with rule 76
- vector information in accordance with rule 77
- the accuracy class of each boundary point
- occupation information in accordance with rule 79
- survey mark and point information in accordance with rule 80
- at least 1 measured vector to every new or old survey mark
- measured vectors to at least 2 other non-boundary marks for every new non-boundary mark
- the adopted vectors or calculated vectors used for the purpose of boundary definition
- a dataset description

A record of survey must include all of the following information about an occupation in graphic form:
- the nature of the physical feature
- the age of the physical feature
- the relationship between the occupation and the boundary or boundary position.

A record of survey must include the relationship between an occupation and a boundary or boundary position in graphic form by any of the following:
- by vector
- by distance
- by description.

A record of survey must record occupation information for each of the following:
- a new boundary point on a primary parcel
- an existing boundary point that is being marked
- an existing boundary point that is required to be marked.

A record of survey must record a no occupation" annotation against a boundary point and related boundaries if there is no occupation and the record of survey includes information about any of the following:
- a new boundary point on a primary parcel
- an existing boundary point that is being marked
- an existing boundary point that is required to be marked."

A record of survey must include the source CSD reference for all of the following:
- each adopted vector
- each adopted distance
- each adopted bearing
- each adopted arc.
A record of survey must include any bearing adjustment that is applied to each CSD from which a bearing is adopted.

A record of survey must include information identifying if any bearing included in the record of survey is any of the following:
- a calculated bearing
- a measured bearing
- an adopted bearing.

A record of survey must include information identifying if any distance included in the record of survey is any of the following:
- a calculated distance
- a measured distance
- an adopted distance.

A record of survey must include information identifying if any arc included in the record of survey is any of the following:
- a calculated arc
- a measured arc
- an adopted arc.

Signifier: Reference mark for height limited boundary
Statement: Reference mark for height limited boundary
column4: A cadastral survey must consist of at least two permanent reference marks that have reduced levels if the cadastral survey has a referenced height-limited boundary point.
A new height limited boundary point on a unit parcel must be referenced by a permanent reference mark.

A new height limited boundary point on a parcel need not be referenced by a permanent reference mark only if the parcel is any of the following:
- an easement parcel
- a lease
- a covenant parcel.
A new height limited boundary point that coincides with an accepted boundary need not be referenced by a permanent reference mark.

A new height limited boundary point on a unit parcel required to be referenced by a permanent reference mark must be less than or equal to 150 m distant from a permanent reference mark if the accuracy class of the boundary point is class A.

A new height limited boundary point on a unit parcel required to be referenced by a permanent reference mark must be less than or equal to 500 m distant from a permanent reference mark if the accuracy class of the boundary point is class B.
A cadastral survey that includes a height limited boundary point must include at least 2 permanent reference marks with reduced levels.
A survey mark must be considered a new survey mark if the survey mark is a reinstated survey mark.

A reinstatement diagram for a simple boundary reinstatement CSD must include the following:
- a depiction of all survey marks and their unique names (which may be in abbreviated form)
- a depiction of all measured vectors between all survey marks, but is not required to show the bearings and distances
- a depiction of the primary parcel boundaries being reinstated
- the appellation of the parcel whose boundary is being reinstated
- the name or (if no name is available) a simple description of any road, railway, or water body that abuts the boundaries being reinstated.

Signifier: Reinstatement diagram plan symbols and text
Statement: Reinstatement diagram plan symbols and text
column4: Information on a reinstatement diagram must conform to the symbol, line style, and text requirements specified in Schedule 7.
A survey mark must be considered a new survey mark if the survey mark is a renewed survey mark.

A new parcel must be created by a cadastral survey for each portion of an existing covenant parcel that is revoked and that remains if part of the covenant is revoked and the underlying parcel of that covenant parcel is not created by that cadastral survey.

Signifier: Rule 10001 (copy of Derivation of class A boundary is subject to conflict 1)
Statement: Rule 10001 (copy of Derivation of class A boundary is subject to conflict 1)
column4: A boundary must be considered a boundary subject to conflict if all of the following are true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the boundary is an existing boundary\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the accuracy [relative] between a boundary point that is included in the boundary and a boundary point that is included in an estate boundary that coincides with the boundary is not class A.

Signifier: Rule 10001 (copy of Minimum PRMs in a cadastral survey)
Statement: Rule 10001 (copy of Minimum PRMs in a cadastral survey)
column4: A cadastral survey that includes a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel and not accurately related to a boundary defining an underlying parcel must include at least 3 permanent reference marks for which any of the following is true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the permanent reference mark is not more than 150 m from a class a boundary point that is included in a boundary defining a non-primary parcel and not accurately related to a boundary defining an underlying parcel \u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the permanent reference mark is not more than 500 m from a class b boundary point that is included in a boundary defining a non-primary parcel and not accurately related to a boundary defining an underlying parcel.

Signifier: Rule 10001 (copy of Rule 10001 (copy of Derivation of boundary is subject to conflict))
Statement: Rule 10001 (copy of Rule 10001 (copy of Derivation of boundary is subject to conflict))
column4:
copy of copy of A boundary must be considered to be a boundary that is subject to conflict when all of the following are true:
- there is a difference that exceeds the applicable accuracy standards between any of the following:
- - an estate boundary and the coinciding boundary recorded in an approved CSD
- - the same boundary as recorded in different approved CSDs
- - the same boundary as recorded in an approved CSD and other evidence, including field evidence
- the difference has not been resolved by 1 or more approved CSDs.

Signifier: Rule 10001 (copy of Rule 10001 (copy of Minimum PRMs in a cadastral survey))
Statement: Rule 10001 (copy of Rule 10001 (copy of Minimum PRMs in a cadastral survey))
column4: A cadastral survey that includes a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel that overlies a parcel that is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake must include at least 3 permanent reference marks for which any of the following is true:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the permanent reference mark is not more than 150 m from a class a boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel that overlies a parcel that is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the permanent reference mark is not more than 500 m from a class b boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a non-primary parcel that overlies a parcel that is the bed of a stream or the bed of a river or the bed of a lake.
A CSD must be the source of information for an adopted value if that CSD measured or calculated the adopted value.

Signifier: Source of adopted water or irregular boundary
Statement: Source of adopted water or irregular boundary
column4: A CSD must be the source of information for an adopted water or irregular boundary if that CSD measured or defined the adopted boundary.

Signifier: Statutory water body width and water or irregular boundaries
Statement: Statutory water body width and water or irregular boundaries
column4: A water or irregular boundary that is not an accepted boundary must have its position determined to a level of accuracy [positional] that prevents a parcel defined by the boundary infringing any statutory requirement applying to the width or size of a water body that adjoins the boundary.
A survey diagram must clearly depict the annotations related to the each relevant boundaries included in the survey diagram according to the boundary annotations for survey diagrams table.
A survey report included in a CSD must contain an explanation for not including a certification of survey plan approval if the CSD is for a Crown subdivision.

A survey report included in a CSD must contain the following reasons about marks where applicable:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- reasons why it was impracticable for a mark to be placed at a new boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a new primary parcel \u003Cbr/\u003E\n- reasons why it was impracticable for a mark to be placed at a boundary point that is included in an existing boundary that defines a new primary parcel.

A survey report included in a CSD must contain details to support the exemption of a mark to be placed at a new boundary point that is included in a boundary that defines a new primary parcel in the following circumstances:
- all parcels that are adjacent to the boundary point are new parcels intended to be owned by the Crown
- all parcels that are adjacent to the boundary point are new parcels intended to be owned by the same territorial authority
- the Maori Land Court does not require a mark to be placed at a boundary point that is included in the boundary
- all parcels that are adjacent to the boundary point are or will be held in common ownership
- the parcels on each side of the boundary are or will be subject to a reciprocal right of way
- the terrain, ground cover, or protected vegetation make it unlikely that the boundary point will need to be physically located.

A new parcel must be created by a cadastral survey for each portion of an existing easement parcel that is surrendered and that remains if part of the easement is surrendered and the underlying parcel of that easement parcel is not created by that cadastral survey.
A survey diagram must depict a water or irregular boundary at a scale that is adequate to meet the accuracy [positional] required for the water or irregular boundary.

Signifier: Survey diagram height limit boundaries information
Statement: Survey diagram height limit boundaries information
column4: A survey diagram must show sufficient information to enable the relationship between any position on a height limited boundary surface and another boundary that defines the same parcel to be accurately ascertained for a height limited boundary that is mathematically described.

Signifier: Survey diagram horizontal extent  boundary relationship parcel information
Statement: Survey diagram horizontal extent  boundary relationship parcel information
column4: A survey diagram must include a depiction of the relationships between a parcel and its boundaries and boundary points in the horizontal extent.

Signifier: Survey diagram horizontal extent of parcel information
Statement: Survey diagram horizontal extent of parcel information
column4: A survey diagram must include a depiction of the horizontal extent of each parcel that is not a balance parcel in the CSD.

A survey diagram must depict a water or irregular boundary at a scale that clearly shows all of the following:\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the shape of the boundary\u003Cbr/\u003E\n- the relationship of the boundary to other boundaries.

Signifier: Survey diagram movable marginal strip information
Statement: Survey diagram movable marginal strip information
column4: A survey diagram must depict a parcel that is a movable marginal strip as being contained within the underlying primary parcel of the movable marginal strip.

Signifier: Survey diagram non primary parcel information
Statement: Survey diagram non primary parcel information
column4: A survey diagram must include a depiction of the boundaries that define any non-primary parcel and the boundaries of underlying parcel of the non-primary parcel so that the location of the non-primary parcel within the underlying parcel is clear and unambiguous.
A survey diagram must include a north point shown on every sheet of the survey diagram.
A survey diagram must clearly depict the annotations related to the each relevant parcel included in the survey diagram according to the parcel annotations for survey diagrams table.
A survey diagram must include a depiction of the appellation of each new parcel in the CSD.

The information included in a survey diagram must be all of the following:
- clear
- unambiguous
- legible when printed at A3 size.

The diagram plan symbols and text information on a survey diagram must conform to all of the following requirements specified in the symbols for survey marks table:
- symbol requirements
- line style requirements
- text requirements.

Signifier: Survey diagram unique parcel appellation information
Statement: Survey diagram unique parcel appellation information
column4: The depiction of the appellation of each new parcel in a CSD that is included in a survey diagram may be abbreviated only if the appellation is unique.

A survey diagram must include:
- at least 1 measured vector to every survey mark
- measured vectors to at least 2 other non-boundary marks for every new non-boundary mark that is not disturbed
